Package thirdparty.net.oelen.polsolve.jt

Class CPoly

java.lang.Object
thirdparty.net.oelen.polsolve.jt.CPoly
public class CPoly extends Object

Represents a polynomial equation of the form p(x) = A + B*x + C*x^2 + D*x^3 + ... where A, B, C, etc are either real or complex coefficients.

Includes a method for finding the zeros of a complex polynomial by the three stage complex algorithm of Jenkins and Traub. The method finds the zeros one at a time in roughly increasing order of modulus and deflates the polynomial to one of lower degree. This method is extremely fast and timing is quite insensitive to distribution of zeros.

Zero finder ported from FORTRAN version of algorithm 419 courtesy Netlib Repository.

This class is not thread-safe.

Modified by: Joseph A. Huwaldt Wilco Oelen

Version:
October 6, 2015
Author:
Joseph A. Huwaldt Date: July 15, 2000, Wilco Oelen

  • Constructor Details

    • CPoly

      public CPoly(double[] coef)
      Constructor that takes an array of real coefficients. Coefficients are supplied in order of increasing power. Example: p(x) = A + B*x + C*x^2 + D*x^3 + E*x^4 gives coefficients[] = {A, B, C, D, E}. The degree of the polynomial is equal to the length of the supplied array minus 1.
      Parameters:
      coef - An array of real coefficients in order of increasing power.

    • CPoly

      public CPoly(double[] coef_re, double[] coef_im)
      Constructor that takes an array with the real part of coefficients and an array with the imaginary part of the coefficients. Coefficients are supplied in order of increasing power. Example: p(x) = A + B*x + C*x^2 + D*x^3 + E*x^4 gives coefficients[] = {A, B, C, D, E}. The degree of the polynomial is determined by the length of the longest supplied array. If the longest supplied array has N elements, then the degree of the polynomial equals N-1. The shorter array is extended with zero values for the higher powers. E.g. a polynomial with arrays {1,2,3} and {11,22,33,44,55} has degree 4 and can be written as (1+11i) + (2+22i)*x + (3+33i)*x^2 + 44i*x^3 + 55i*x^4
      Parameters:
      coef_re - An array containing the real part of the coefficients in order of increasing power. If the supplied array equals null, then the degree is determined by the length of the other array and the real part of all coefficients equals 0 in that case.
      coef_im - An array containing the imaginary part of the coefficients in order of increasing power. If the supplied array equals null, then the degree is determined by the length of the other array and the imaginary part of all coefficients equals 0 in that case.

  • Method Details

    • eval

      public double[] eval(double xre, double xim)
      Evaluates the polynomial at a complex point, specified by the arguments.
      Parameters:
      xre - The real part of the point at which the polynomial is evaluated.
      xim - The imaginary part of the point at which the polynomial is evaluated.
      Returns:
      A double[] array, with the value at index 0 being the real part of the evaluated value and the value at index 1 being the imaginary part of the evaluated value.

    • eval

      public void eval(double[] result, double xre, double xim)
      Evaluates the polynomial at the given complex argument. This is like the other eval() method, but in this one the result of the evaluation is put in an array, which already is allocated in the calling environment. This method allows many evaluations of the polynomial without the need to allocate many small 2-element arrays for storing the result.
      Parameters:
      result - A double-array with at least two elements, in which the result of the evaluation is stored. The value at index 0 is replaced by the real part of the polynomial value and the value at index 1 is replaced by the imaginary part of the polynomial value. If the supplied array contains more than 2 elements, then the elements with index 2 or larger are not touched at all.
      xre - The real part of the argument at which the polynomial is evaluated.
      xim - The imaginary part of the argument at which the polynomial is evaluated.

    • eval_deriv

      public void eval_deriv(double[] result, double[] dresult, double xre, double xim)
      Evaluates the polynomial and the derivative of the polynomial simultaneously for the given value of x.
      Parameters:
      result - A double-array with at least two elements, in which the result of the evaluation is stored. The value at index 0 is replaced by the real part of the polynomial value and the value at index 1 is replaced by the imaginary part of the polynomial value. If the supplied array contains more than 2 elements, then the elements with index 2 or larger are not touched at all.
      dresult - A double-array with at least two elements, in which the result of the evaluation is stored. The value at index 0 is replaced by the real part of the derivative value and the value at index 1 is replaced by the imaginary part of the derivative value. If the supplied array contains more than 2 elements, then the elements with index 2 or larger are not touched at all.
      xre - The real part of the argument at which the derivative is evaluated.
      xim - The imaginary part of the argument at which the derivative is evaluated.

    • solve

      public int solve(double[] zeror, double[] zeroi)
      This method computes the roots of the polynomial and stores the roots in preallocated arrays, which are passed as arguments.
      Parameters:
      zeror - Array, in which the real parts of the zeros will be stored after computation of the zeros. This array must have a length of at least N elements, where N is the degree of the polynomial.
      zeroi - Array, in which the imaginary parts of the zeros will be stored after computation of the zeros. This array must have a length of at least N elements, where N is the degree of the polynomial.
      Returns:
      Returns the degree of the polynomial if the computation succeeds, and returns a value less than the degree of the polynomial if an error occurs (e.g. convergence failure). When a value less than the degree of the polynomial is returned, then only part (or none) of the roots could be determined.
